linkTarget.anchoringText: As the fracturing fluid propagates through the tensile deformation of the rock and meets the natural fracture, the natural fracture properties and pressure in the induced fracture determine either of the three outcomes: the hydraulic fracture may propagate through the natural fracture, the hydraulic fracture may be arrested by the natural fracture, or the hydraulic fracture may intersect and propagate in the natural fracture and subsequently cross it (Fig. 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Hydraulic fracture propagation and interaction with a natural fracture.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Hydraulic fracture propagation and interaction with a natural fracture.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Recently, Cohen et al. (2017) presented a theoretical approach to account for vertical heterogeneity in the natural fracture network (Fig. 2) as they modified the fracture model to honor the crossing criteria developed by Gu and Weng (2010), but over different vertical layers as per the DFN variability, hence, the multilayer DFN (MDFN). However, there has been no application presented in the literature to evaluate the use of an MDFN coupled to a complex fracture model in predicting the fracture geometry in shale reservoirs. The purpose of this study, therefore, is to provide supplemental evidence and a workflow for applying the MDFN approach wherever applicable for improving the predictability of well completions and their production performance.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: MDFN model (Cohen et al. 2017).

formatted-caption.caption-text: MDFN model (Cohen et al. 2017).

linkTarget.bib:
Cohen et al., 2017
C.-E. Cohen , O. Kresse , and X. Weng
2017. Stacked Height Model to Improve Fracture Height Growth Prediction, and Simulate Interactions With Multi-Layer DFNs and Ledges at Weak Zone Interfaces. Presented at the SPE Hydraulic Fracturing Technology Conference, The Woodlands, Texas, USA, 24-26 January . SPE-184876-MS. https://doi.org/10.2118/184876-MS

linkTarget.anchoringText: The horizontal well studied by Ajisafe et al. (2016) and here in this paper was drilled to target the Avalon shale in the Delaware basin with 11 fracturing stages completed with the plug-and-perforation technique. The DFN model shows variation in all three dimensions around the wellbore. Therefore, the hydraulic fracture geometry expected in the wellbore had bearing on the density of natural fractures and their distribution. This was also indicated by the microseismic data collected during the stimulation because they show variance along the wellbore (Fig. 3) as well as vertically (Fig. 4).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Top view of the microseismic data along the wellbore and DFN in a horizontal cross-section in the plane of the wellbore.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Top view of the microseismic data along the wellbore and DFN in a horizontal cross-section in the plane of the wellbore.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The horizontal well studied by Ajisafe et al. (2016) and here in this paper was drilled to target the Avalon shale in the Delaware basin with 11 fracturing stages completed with the plug-and-perforation technique. The DFN model shows variation in all three dimensions around the wellbore. Therefore, the hydraulic fracture geometry expected in the wellbore had bearing on the density of natural fractures and their distribution. This was also indicated by the microseismic data collected during the stimulation because they show variance along the wellbore (Fig. 3) as well as vertically (Fig. 4).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Side view of the microseismic data along the wellbore and DFN in a vertical crosssection in the plane of wellbore showing natural fractures terminating at different depths.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Side view of the microseismic data along the wellbore and DFN in a vertical crosssection in the plane of wellbore showing natural fractures terminating at different depths.

linkTarget.anchoringText: A geocellular model is created around the wellbore. This geocellular model comprises geomechanical and petrophysical properties defined for each layer. The small sector model of DFN is created for the area of interest using the larger DFN model prepared by Ajisafe et al. (2016). The DFN model is then discretized into various elements represented across the layers in Avalon shale. This allows creating a subdivision of the 3D DFN model as per the layers defined in the geocellular model (Fig. 5). The MDFN created in this study is different from that presented by Ajisafe et al. (2016) where they had considered a SDFN.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Side view of DFN network. A) MDFN shows variability of the DFN model when fracture sets vary vertically for properties. B) SDFN cut across the horizontal wellbore.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Side view of DFN network. A) MDFN shows variability of the DFN model when fracture sets vary vertically for properties. B) SDFN cut across the horizontal wellbore.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: MDFN shows variability of the DFN model when fracture sets vary vertically for properties
SDFN cut across the horizontal wellbore.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Hydraulic fracture geometry for the stage 1 is represented in Fig. 6A and Fig. 6C using the MDFN approach and Fig. 6B and Fig. 6D using the SDNF approach. The hydraulic fracture with the MDFN shows greater complexity and variation of the hydraulic fracture dimensions in the vertical direction than with the SDFN, which essentially creates a vertical plane of fracture with complexity in the horizontal direction only.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Stage 1 fracture model. A) Side view using the MDFN approach, B) side view using the SDFN approach, C) top view using the MDFN approach, and D) top view using the SDFN approach.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Stage 1 fracture model. A) Side view using the MDFN approach, B) side view using the SDFN approach, C) top view using the MDFN approach, and D) top view using the SDFN approach.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Side view using the MDFN approach,
side view using the SDFN approach,
top view using the MDFN approach, and
top view using the SDFN approach.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The hydraulic fracturing treatment pressure response on the surface may not be very different between the two approaches. The fracture treatment pressure history was plotted together for both the scenarios, and it was found that the stimulation pressure history for both the cases were very similar. The surface areas created by the two fracture simulation cases have only a minor difference at the end; the case with the MDFN adds just over 18% higher surface area due to added complexity with more natural fracture interaction (Fig. 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Treatment pressure history for the MDFN and SDFN cases show similar pressure profile and around 18% higher surface area with SDFN model.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Treatment pressure history for the MDFN and SDFN cases show similar pressure profile and around 18% higher surface area with SDFN model.

linkTarget.anchoringText: When the fracture surface areas for all the clusters are compared, the surface area created using SDFN is, on an average, similar to the surface area using the MDFN approach. There is some minor variability between the two cases, as seen in Fig. 8. However, when the propped fraction of the hydraulic fractures is computed, we observe that the model predicts greater propped surface area with the SDFN than with the MDFN approach (Fig. 9) due to the fact that the proppant transport is compromised at an increased complexity.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Total fracture surface area from the two models.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Total fracture surface area from the two models.

linkTarget.anchoringText: When the fracture surface areas for all the clusters are compared, the surface area created using SDFN is, on an average, similar to the surface area using the MDFN approach. There is some minor variability between the two cases, as seen in Fig. 8. However, when the propped fraction of the hydraulic fractures is computed, we observe that the model predicts greater propped surface area with the SDFN than with the MDFN approach (Fig. 9) due to the fact that the proppant transport is compromised at an increased complexity.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Propped surface area from the two models.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Propped surface area from the two models.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The maximum surface pressures for the two approaches of modeling show a similar pressure trend. Fig. 10 shows the maximum surface pressure modeled by the two approaches. Therefore, execution data from the field may not be enough to determine if the fractures are creating additional complexity in the vertical direction due to interaction with natural fractures or whether the fracture is only creating complexity in the horizontal plane of propagation. Advanced modeling as proposed in this study can only predict the response and hydraulic fracture complexity with varying DFN vertically.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Maximum surface pressure from the two models.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Maximum surface pressure from the two models.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The fluid efficiency of the treatments was compared, and it is observed that the fracturing fluid efficiency of the MDFN approach is higher by approximately 5 to 20% compared to the SDFN approach (Fig.11), and this explains the higher surface area created in the model through the MDFN approach as seen in previous Fig. 10.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Fracturing fluid efficiency from the two models.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fracturing fluid efficiency from the two models.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Hydraulic fracture extent compared for the two approaches is summarized in Fig. 12, and it is observed that the fracture extent through the SDFN modeling is greater than with the MDFN. This is attributed to less complexity and interaction with the simplistic natural fracture representation in SDFN whereas when more realistic MDFN approach is used, the hydraulic fractures tend to be smaller in extent. This can have a direct impact on well spacing decisions.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Fracture extent from the two models.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fracture extent from the two models.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The hydraulic fracture height in the MDFN approach shows significant reduction (Fig. 13) since the hydraulic fractures tend to get more complex in the horizontal plane and vary over the vertical dimension as they meet the natural fractures.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Maximum fracture height from the two models.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Maximum fracture height from the two models.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Hydraulic fracture simulation with the complex fracture model was performed to create the fracture geometry for the treatment stages. Fig. 14 represents the fracture footprint of stage 1 as predicted by the simulation from a top view and overlaid with the microseismic event data collected during the actual treatment.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Microseismic data measured around stage 1 overlaid with A) the fracture using MDFN and B) the fracture using SDFN, in top view.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Microseismic data measured around stage 1 overlaid with A) the fracture using MDFN and B) the fracture using SDFN, in top view.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: the fracture using SDFN, in top view.

linkTarget.anchoringText: When the stage 1 treatment design and fracture geometry with the MDFN is compared to the stage 1 simulation results with SDFN, it is seen that due to the presence of more-intense natural fracture representation vertically, the hydraulic fracture propagation is shortened marginally in the x-y plane as the total mass of fluid and proppant is conserved. It is also seen that the microseismic data acquired from the wellsite during the treatment, as shown in the yellow dots in Fig 13, match better to the fracture footprint considering the MDFN representation of natural fractures. Further, a side view of the stage 1 is also compared visually and the microseismic data are much better covered by the fracture geometry from MDFN approach (Fig. 15).

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Microseismic data measured around stage 1 overlaid with A) fracture using MDFN and B) fracture using SDFN in side view.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Microseismic data measured around stage 1 overlaid with A) fracture using MDFN and B) fracture using SDFN in side view.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: fracture using SDFN in side view.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The hydraulic fracture extents predicted with the SDFN case represented in Fig. 16 are, in general, larger than the observed microseismic data. Additionally, some of the stages had shown greater intensity of microseismic data near the wellbore whereas the fracture geometry from the SDFN is more disperse and planar. When the MDFN is used, the predicted hydraulic fractures present a greater degree of complexity around the regions where there is denser natural fracture intensity and correlate better with the observed microseismic data.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Microseismic data measured on full wellbore with A) fracture using MDFN and B) fracture using SDFN in top view

formatted-caption.caption-text: Microseismic data measured on full wellbore with A) fracture using MDFN and B) fracture using SDFN in top view

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: fracture using SDFN in top view

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 17 compares the synthetic microseismic data predicted from FEM shown in cyan-colored dots for stage 1 considering the MFDN with the real microseismic data acquired on Stage 1 shown in the yellow-colored dots. When the fracture geometry extracted from the SDFN modeling approach is used, the predicted synthetic microseismic events for the stage 1 stimulation treatment do not show coherence with the actual observed microseismic data (Fig. 18).

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Measured microseismic data (yellow) compared to synthetic microseismic data (cyan) in MDFN approach.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Measured microseismic data (yellow) compared to synthetic microseismic data (cyan) in MDFN approach.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 17 compares the synthetic microseismic data predicted from FEM shown in cyan-colored dots for stage 1 considering the MFDN with the real microseismic data acquired on Stage 1 shown in the yellow-colored dots. When the fracture geometry extracted from the SDFN modeling approach is used, the predicted synthetic microseismic events for the stage 1 stimulation treatment do not show coherence with the actual observed microseismic data (Fig. 18).

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Measured microseismic data (yellow) compared to synthetic microseismic data (green) in the SDFN approach

formatted-caption.caption-text: Measured microseismic data (yellow) compared to synthetic microseismic data (green) in the SDFN approach

linkTarget.anchoringText: From the presentation above, it is seen that the predicted synthetic microseismic data follow a trend and exhibit a density similar to those of the measured microseismic data. Further, to quantify the space that is stimulated by the hydraulic fractures, the cloud of the microseismic data is evaluated via visual analytics tools to represent the fraction of space covered by the microseismic data in different views (Fig. 19,Fig. 20, and Fig. 21). The fraction of the surface area covering the space around the full wellbore is computed with synthetic microseismic and real microseismic data in different views and represented in the bar chart in Fig. 22.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Top view of the full wellbore, measured microseismic data compared to synthetic microseismic data in the MDFN approach.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Top view of the full wellbore, measured microseismic data compared to synthetic microseismic data in the MDFN approach.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In addition to purely visual interpretation, the stress-drop magnitude of the microseismic events measured on the wellsite and synthetic microseismic with the MDFN are compared. The histograms and distribution of the microseismic events for the measured DFN and the computed synthetic DFN, shown in Fig. 23 and Fig. 24, respectively, are similar.

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: Histogram of stress drop of real, measured microseismic data.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Histogram of stress drop of real, measured microseismic data.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In addition to purely visual interpretation, the stress-drop magnitude of the microseismic events measured on the wellsite and synthetic microseismic with the MDFN are compared. The histograms and distribution of the microseismic events for the measured DFN and the computed synthetic DFN, shown in Fig. 23 and Fig. 24, respectively, are similar.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Pressure depletion around the hydraulic fracture geometry is shown in Fig. 25 using the MDFN approach and in Fig. 26 using the SDFN approach. It is seen that the pressure depletion using the MDFN method for fracture modeling shows weaker depletion.

image-wrap.label: Figure 25
image-wrap.caption: Pressure depletion map on a cross section across the wellbore, MDFN approach.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pressure depletion map on a cross section across the wellbore, MDFN approach.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Pressure depletion around the hydraulic fracture geometry is shown in Fig. 25 using the MDFN approach and in Fig. 26 using the SDFN approach. It is seen that the pressure depletion using the MDFN method for fracture modeling shows weaker depletion.

image-wrap.label: Figure 26
image-wrap.caption: Pressure depletion map on a cross section across the wellbore, SDFN approach.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pressure depletion map on a cross section across the wellbore, SDFN approach.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The proppant distribution due to increased fracture complexity is compromised. As seen in Fig. 27A, the proppants in the fractured modeled using the SDFN approach show a large fraction of fracture geometry as propped fracture filled with 100-mesh sand, 40/70 sand, or 20/40 sand. On the other hand, the unpropped portion of the hydraulic fractures in the geometry modeled using the MDFN approach are fairly extensive (Fig. 28A). Therefore, as a result of enhanced fracture conductivity, the effective extents of the hydraulic fracture contributing to production are overestimated using the SDFN fracture modeling approach (Fig. 27B) as compared to MDFN approach (Fig. 28B).

image-wrap.label: Figure 27
image-wrap.caption: A) Proppant distribution in the fractures with the SDFN model and B) pressure depletion in the fracture cells with the SDFN model.

formatted-caption.caption-text: A) Proppant distribution in the fractures with the SDFN model and B) pressure depletion in the fracture cells with the SDFN model.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution in the fractures with the SDFN model and
pressure depletion in the fracture cells with the SDFN model.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The proppant distribution due to increased fracture complexity is compromised. As seen in Fig. 27A, the proppants in the fractured modeled using the SDFN approach show a large fraction of fracture geometry as propped fracture filled with 100-mesh sand, 40/70 sand, or 20/40 sand. On the other hand, the unpropped portion of the hydraulic fractures in the geometry modeled using the MDFN approach are fairly extensive (Fig. 28A). Therefore, as a result of enhanced fracture conductivity, the effective extents of the hydraulic fracture contributing to production are overestimated using the SDFN fracture modeling approach (Fig. 27B) as compared to MDFN approach (Fig. 28B).

image-wrap.label: Figure 28
image-wrap.caption: A) Proppant distribution in the fractures with MDFN model and B) pressure depletion in the fracture cells with the MDFN model.

formatted-caption.caption-text: A) Proppant distribution in the fractures with MDFN model and B) pressure depletion in the fracture cells with the MDFN model.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution in the fractures with MDFN model and
pressure depletion in the fracture cells with the MDFN model.

linkTarget.anchoringText: As we know, history matching of reservoir deliverability is a non-unique solution. However, if the SDFN approach is chosen, the production history matching parameters are significantly different from those in the MDFN approach because the behavior for the production is different (Fig. 29) due to the fracture geometry and conductivity distribution.

image-wrap.label: Figure 29
image-wrap.caption: Production prediction with SDFN (dotted lines) and MDFN (solid lines) modeling approaches.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production prediction with SDFN (dotted lines) and MDFN (solid lines) modeling approaches.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In 1957, Howard and Fast published the first mathematical model that an engineer could use to design a fracture treatment. The Howard and Fast model assumed the fracture width was constant everywhere, allowing the engineer to compute fracture area on the basis of fracture fluid leakoff characteristics of the formation and the fracturing fluid. As the industry developed, the modeling of hydraulic fractures evolved. Fracture modeling has advanced from the early concepts of 2D models such as PKN, KGD to Pseudo 3D models with no natural fracture impact on hydraulic fracture geometry to the newer complex fracture models accounting for MDFN with predicting the transport of fluids and proppants more rigorously (Fig. 30).

image-wrap.label: Figure 30
image-wrap.caption: Evolution of hydraulic fracture modeling approaches.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Evolution of hydraulic fracture modeling approaches.
